This holistic approach requires integrating sustainable agricultural practices, supportive policies, and cross-sector collaboration. Prioritizing soil health will help build a resilient food system that benefits both people and the planet (Sahu and Gupta, 2024). Recognizing and acting on the interconnectedness of these elements is essential for providing future generations with the nutritious food needed for healthy, fulfilling lives.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Strategies for sustainable fertilizer use and soil health promotion
Preserving and adding up soil organic matter: adopting alternative agricultural practices
ce:section.ce:para: Intensive agriculture erodes soil organic matter, compromising its health and productivity. This leads to increased reliance on fertilizers and water, amplifying CO2 emissions (Mishra et al., 2022). "Sustainable agriculture," coined in the late 1980s, focuses on enhancing soil health by bolstering organic matter and reducing erosion (Pinheiro Machado Filho et al., 2021). Introduced by the National Research Council and later included in the US Agriculture 1990 Farm Bill, it aims for economic viability while minimizing external inputs (Dimitri and Effland, 2020). Varied practices like agroecology, integrated farming, and precision agriculture fall under this framework, which isn't fixed and might include agrochemicals like synthetic fertilizers and pesticides within certain strategies. The core remains holistic, conserving resources while diversifying approaches (Kumar et al., 2023).

Soil erosion resistance relies on soil organic matter (SOM) and plant cover. Regions like Asia and Africa grapple with severe erosion, risking soil carbon loss and landscape devastation (Salim and Raza, 2020). SOM's role in drought-resistant soil and sustainable food production is pivotal, fostering erosion-resistant soil aggregates. Fertile soils can contain up to 100 tonnes of organic matter per hectare (around 4 % of total soil weight), while SOM typically represents 1–5 % of agricultural topsoil (Voltr et al., 2021). Conventional farming practices exacerbate topsoil erosion and SOM loss, removing up to 5 times more organic matter-rich soil. This topsoil layer holds 95 % of soil nitrogen and 25–50 % of soil phosphorus, essential for soil fertility (Blanco and Lal, 2023).

No-till or minimum-tillage methods, coupled with organic farming, combat soil loss, bolster soil organic matter, and revive fertility and biodiversity (Khangura et al., 2023). These practices reduce erosion, pollution, and benefit ecosystems while boosting agronomic output and food security (Abay et al., 2022). However, complete reliance on no-till may require supplementary measures like cover crops or proper rotations, particularly when combined with excessive agrochemical use (Blanco and Lal, 2023). Recent discussions question its efficacy as a carbon sink and in mitigating climate change. Nevertheless, no-till methods offer significant advantages, slashing energy usage by 70 %, and reducing herbicide and pesticide application by 50 %, thereby mitigating fossil fuel emissions and hazardous chemical dispersion (Yin et al., 2021).

Soils with 1 % soil organic matter (SOM) can retain 10,000–11,000 litres of plant-available water per hectare to a depth of 30 cm (Voltr et al., 2021). Organic crops often outperform conventional ones in drought conditions, showing a 70 %−90 % advantage. This advantage arises from the superior water-holding capacity of organically managed soil, offering up to 100 % more water in the crop root zone (Khangura et al., 2023). Organic systems display reduced production variability and increased stability. Additionally, low-input methods like organic farming significantly enhance soil biological activity, supporting diverse microbial life critical for sustainable soil health and productivity (Almansa et al., 2023).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Adoption of precision agriculture techniques
ce:section.ce:para: Conventional fertilizer methods often lack precision, leading to issues like yield reduction, increased costs, and environmental risks (Karunathilake et al., 2023). Soil and plant sensing technology presents a solution, offering real-time insights into soil and plant nutrient status (Munnaf et al., 2021). These sensors measure various soil and plant parameters - pH, electrical conductivity, nutrient content, and chlorophyll levels - improving fertilizer precision (Yin et al., 2021). Soil sensors gauge pH, temperature, moisture, and nutrients, while plant sensors like the Parrot Pot, Edyn Garden sensor, and Koubachi Wi-Fi sensor monitor plant height, chlorophyll content, and water status (Karunathilake et al., 2023). This real-time data aids in fine-tuning fertilizer application, ensuring precise nutrient delivery and optimizing plant growth and health (Munnaf et al., 2021).

In rainfed conditions, optimizing fertilizer use efficiency involves estimating soil moisture using diverse sensors (Yin et al., 2021). Capacitance types like Decagon Devices EC-5, Chirp, and Sentek Technologies, alongside resistance types such as FC-28, YL-69, and V1.2, and time domain reflectometry (TDR) examples like Decagon Devices Inc. EM50-TDR, Campbell Scientific CS616, and METER Group, Inc. C-Probe sensors aid in continuous soil moisture monitoring (Dubois, 2021). These sensors, coupled with data loggers, enable real-time field deployment. Predictive irrigation systems, integrating sensor data with weather forecasts and evapotranspiration models, enhance irrigation decisions by 25 % (Yartu et al., 2022). GIS tools, like the Agricultural Decision Support System (ADSS), fuse spatial data with soil and crop yield information, empowering farmers to discern patterns in crop yields, soil fertility, and plant health (Dadrasi et al., 2022). Fig. 7 demonstrates sustainable management techniques for improving soil health and food security. This insight helps make informed decisions on fertilization and management practices.

To determine soil properties like total nitrogen, machine learning (ML) algorithms coupled with spectroscopy are utilized (Xu et al., 2024). Integrating ML with Internet of Things (IoT) data transforms farm management into sophisticated AI systems, offering insightful recommendations for improved productivity (Ennaji et al., 2023). Partial Least Square Regression (PLSR) is commonly used for accurate multivariable predictions. PLSR involves deriving linear combinations of spectra, effectively explaining response variation while handling predictor differences (Dubois, 2021). Widely used in soil spectroscopy, it's successful in evaluating water and nitrogen status. Challenges include data availability, training, and model accuracy (Wang et al., 2021). UAV platforms rapidly map NDVI, aiding in Nitrogen Use Efficiency (NUE) assessment. The AS-Scanner ensures swift and precise NDVI acquisition, enabling informed fertilizer decisions, curbing overuse, and mitigating environmental impacts (Jiang et al., 2021). Spectral reflectance from UAV sensors can identify nutrient deficiencies, and toxicity, aiding in holistic plant health analysis, and supporting sustainable farming practices.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Promotion of organic and alternative fertilizers
ce:section.ce:para: Organic fertilizers offer a solution to waste management and soil degradation issues in developing nations (Ayilara et al., 2020). Derived from diverse sources like plant-based substances and animal manure, they vary in nutrient content and types based on materials and biodegradability (Salazar Sandoval et al., 2024). Organic fertilizers contain less nitrogen and phosphorus by weight compared to chemical ones (Shaji et al., 2021). Studies suggest substituting some chemical fertilizers with organic ones to boost soil organic carbon levels and microbial activity, critical for soil health and climate change mitigation (Ayilara et al., 2020).

Organic manures, excluding green manure, are chiefly derived from animal waste and serve as vital sources of nutrients for soil fertility. They aid soil structure and water retention, influencing farming practices based on soil type, crop variety, season, and farmer experience (Shaji et al., 2021). Compost, formed through controlled decomposition of organic matter, benefits from regulated moisture and lime treatment to hasten breakdown and achieve a favourable C/N ratio (Salazar Sandoval et al., 2024). Green manure, youthful plant material, enriches the soil with nitrogen when incorporated, serving as a viable substitute when manure is limited (Fitrah, 2022). Organic farming avoids synthetic inputs, gaining recognition for sustainable food production, and addressing food security concerns with methods prioritizing environmental sustainability (Saffeullah et al., 2021). Fig. 8 depicts the impact of integrated nutrient management on crops and the environment.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Illustrations on management practices to enhance soil health
ce:section.ce:para:
Soil health management hinges on (1) gauging synergies and tradeoffs in techniques; (2) implementing proven, practical conservation methods; and (3) involving stakeholders for widespread adoption (Vanlauwe et al., 2023). The measures listed below help to safeguard soil and ecosystem health while also increasing resistance to climate change.
•
Organic inputs improve soil health and ecosystem functions.
•
Implement climate-specific conservation tillage to reduce soil disturbance.
•
Optimize soil cover with crop rotations, cover crops, agroforestry, and residue degradation.
•
Diversify crop rotation and cover crops to improve soil biota and sustain long-term productivity.
•
Implement Integrated Nutrient Management (INM) strategies that combine organic, biological, and mineral resources.
•
Manage the rhizosphere to optimize nitrogen utilization and crop yield.
•
Reduce soil salinity, alkalinity, acidification, and pollution.
•
Use soil biology technology to select disease-resistant plants and change microbial populations.
•
Use renewable resources instead of manufactured fertilizers to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and petrochemicals.
•
Collaborate with land users to monitor soil health and evaluate the success of applied techniques.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Education and outreach programs for farmers on responsible fertilizer use
ce:section.ce:para: Historically, the fertilizer sector prioritized procedural enhancements over product innovation, as all produced fertilizers were sold. Currently, there's limited focus on renewable resources due to a lack of commercial incentives. Environmental challenges are pushing for technical improvements (Ning et al., 2023). Ammonia production emits CO2, requiring factories to pay for emission permits. While some CO2 is utilized in urea synthesis, a portion is released during application (Ishaq and Crawford, 2024). The circular economy promotes reusing, valorising, recycling, and leveraging natural cycles. Despite significant attention, full implementation is partial. Developing bio-based fertilizer technologies should prioritize minimizing environmental impact, regeneratively using resources, considering scarcity, and ensuring profitability for industrial enterprises (Jagadeesan et al., 2023).

Prioritizing natural resource limitations and environmental conservation while meeting corporate needs is crucial. However, the fertilizer industry often undervalues innovative technologies (Rey-Martínez et al., 2024). For example, using feathers, containing 11 % nitrogen, not only provides nitrogen but also amino acids, serving as a chelating agent for micronutrient ions and a biostimulator for plant growth. This method, if well-structured, emits no emissions and consumes no energy (Jagadeesan et al., 2023). Similarly, in the phosphate fertilizer industry, converting bone meal into hydroxyapatite, which can be broken down like wet phosphoric acid, offers environmental benefits (Kowalski et al., 2023).

The Chinese government implemented policies like soil testing and organic fertilizer subsidies to promote proper fertilizer practices (Ishaq and Crawford, 2024). Farmers often lack crucial knowledge in three domains. First, they lack awareness of fertilizer overuse effects. For instance, Rahman and Zhang (2018) found many aren't aware of their overuse. Second, procedural knowledge, like effective fertilizer usage, is deficient. Wimalawansa and Wimalawansa (2015) noted only 20 % know about eutrophication from over-application. Lastly, conceptual knowledge is lacking the understanding of the underlying reasons behind fertilizer use and its impact on environmental degradation (Kowalski et al., 2023). These gaps hinder effective fertilizer management.

Farmers often believe that more fertilizer leads to higher yields and that cutting fertilizer results in yield losses (Ishaq and Crawford, 2024). These gaps in knowledge hinder eco-friendly technology adoption. Effective knowledge shifts perceptions on fertilizer's environmental impact, fostering change (Jagadeesan et al., 2023). Procedural knowledge addresses inhibiting factors, crucial for behavioural change. Declarative knowledge reduces uncertainty about fertilizer reduction, aiding in mitigating over-application (Rey-Martínez et al., 2024). Enhanced knowledge acquisition is a vital step toward embracing sustainable fertilizer practices in agriculture. Extension technicians play a pivotal role in farmers' knowledge acquisition regarding fertilizer management (Ning et al., 2023). Evaluating training effectiveness could guide governments in designing eco-friendly fertilizer management programs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The three pillars of conservation agriculture: A pathway to sustainable soil health, food security, and human health
ce:section.ce:para: Conservation agriculture is key to sustainable farming, emphasizing minimum soil disturbance, permanent soil cover, and crop diversification. These practices enhance soil health, improve food security, and protect human health, addressing soil degradation and climate change while supporting the broader objectives of the SDGs (Farooq, 2023).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Minimum soil disturbance: preserving soil structure and health
ce:section.ce:para: The first pillar of conservation agriculture focuses on minimizing soil disturbance, primarily through no-till or reduced-till farming. Traditional ploughing disrupts soil structure, causing erosion, loss of organic matter, and a decline in beneficial organisms (Angon et al., 2023). By reducing tillage, soil structure is preserved, maintaining porosity and the network of pores needed for water infiltration and root growth (Farooq, 2023). This practice helps prevent soil compaction, allowing roots to access nutrients and water more effectively. For instance, Li et al. (2020) conducted an intensive meta-analysis of a global dataset from 264 publications on the effects of agronomic and environmental factors on soil physical properties under no-tillage. Compared to conventional tillage, no-tillage increased soil bulk density by 2.3 %, soil penetration resistance by 27.8 % and decreased soil pH by 1.8 %. However, no-tillage improved mean weight diameter and water-stable aggregates by 50 % and 36 %, respectively, and increased soil available water capacity by 8.7 %.

Additionally, minimizing soil disturbance is essential for building and maintaining soil organic matter, crucial for long-term soil health. Organic matter is crucial for nutrient cycling, water retention, and soil fertility. Topa et al. (2021) evaluated SOC storage, pools, bulk density, aggregation, and nutrient availability under no-tillage, chisel, and conventional tillage systems in a long-term experiment. After 10 years of crop rotation, no-tillage had higher total organic carbon in the 0–30 cm soil depth than conventional tillage. In the 0–10 cm depth, no-till and chisel treatments had 7–13 %, 34–35 %, and 9–15 % higher non-labile fraction, very-labile fraction, and total organic carbon, respectively, than conventional tillage.

In contrast, conventional tillage can exacerbate soil erosion, leaving it vulnerable to wind and water damage. By minimizing soil disturbance, conservation agriculture maintains soil structure and uses natural vegetation or crop residues to protect the surface, preserving topsoil and preventing sedimentation in water bodies, which protects water quality (Angon et al., 2023). Additionally, minimal tillage enhances carbon sequestration by keeping soil undisturbed, preventing carbon from being released into the atmosphere as CO2 (Farooq, 2023). Over time, this practice can increase soil carbon stocks, helping to mitigate climate change while boosting soil fertility and productivity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Permanent soil cover: shielding soil and enhancing biodiversity
ce:section.ce:para: The second pillar of conservation agriculture is maintaining a permanent soil cover using cover crops, crop residues, or mulch. This cover is crucial for protecting the soil from erosion, reducing water evaporation, and suppressing weed growth (Francaviglia et al., 2023). It helps preserve soil moisture, regulate soil temperature, and support diverse soil organisms. Permanent soil cover acts as a shield against rainfall impact, reducing surface runoff and soil erosion. For instance, Pheap et al. (2019) reported a 2.6-fold increase in labile carbon stocks in Cambodian soybean fields using stylo and great millet as cover crops compared to those without cover crops. It also slows water flow, allowing more water to infiltrate the soil rather than being lost as runoff (Farooq, 2023). With growing concerns over water scarcity in many regions, this practice is essential for sustaining soil health and enhancing water conservation. Permanent soil cover helps conserve moisture by reducing evaporation, keeping the soil cooler and more humid, which is vital during hot and dry periods. This moisture retention supports crops through droughts and stabilizes food supplies (Francaviglia et al., 2023).

Additionally, permanent soil cover promotes biodiversity both above and below ground. For instance, Mitchell et al. (2017) found a 12 % increase in total N at 0–15 cm depth and 10 % at 15–30 cm depth with cover crops. Similarly, Muhammad et al. (2021) reported 40 %, 51 %, and 24 % increases in microbial biomass C, N, and total phospholipid-derived fatty acids (PLFA), respectively. These increases are attributed to additional C and N inputs from cover crop residues (Schmidt et al., 2019). Cover crops enrich the soil microbial community, boosting total bacteria and fungi by 15 % and 19 %, respectively (Muhammad et al., 2021). Cover crops offer habitat for beneficial insects, pollinators, and natural pest predators, while beneath the surface, it supports microorganisms, earthworms, and other soil fauna crucial for nutrient cycling and soil health. This biodiversity enhances resilience to pests, diseases, and climate variability. The decomposition of organic matter from cover crops or residues enriches the soil by continuously supplying essential nutrients, reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers, which can have negative environmental impacts if overused (Francaviglia et al., 2023).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Crop diversification: building resilience and enhancing productivity
ce:section.ce:para: The third pillar of conservation agriculture is crop diversification, which includes rotating crops or planting a variety of crops together. This practice improves soil health, boosts biodiversity, and enhances resilience to pests, diseases, and climate changes (Ferdinand and Baret, 2024). Methods like intercropping, agroforestry, and incorporating legumes into rotations help prevent issues associated with monoculture, where pests and diseases can accumulate (Moreira et al., 2024). Crop diversification increases soil organic carbon, reducing the reliance on chemical pesticides. For example, incorporating sun hemp (Crotalaria juncea) or forage sorghum (Sorghum bicolor) before soybeans increased soil carbon stores by 6.25 and 2.5 t ha-1, respectively (Rigon and Calonego, 2020).

Different crops also impact soil structure differently; deep-rooted crops like maize can break up compacted layers, improving water infiltration, while shallow-rooted crops stabilize the topsoil and prevent erosion (Ferdinand and Baret, 2024). This diversity contributes to overall soil health and resilience. Crop diversification enhances agricultural productivity by mitigating risks associated with crop failure. Growing a variety of crops reduces reliance on a single crop, which can be vulnerable to market fluctuations, pests, and climate extremes (Bedeke, 2023). This approach not only strengthens food security and improves dietary diversity but also supports essential ecosystem services. Diverse cropping systems boost pollination, enrich soil fertility through nutrient cycling, and offer wildlife habitat (Ferdinand and Baret, 2024). Additionally, diversified farms are more resilient to climate variability and extreme weather events, as varied crops can buffer against droughts, floods, and temperature fluctuations (Moreira et al., 2024).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synergy between the three pillars
ce:section.ce:para: The three pillars of conservation agriculture are interdependent and synergistic. Together, they create a resilient agricultural system that enhances soil health, secures food production, and promotes well-being (Farooq, 2023). This approach aligns with SDG 2 (Zero Hunger), SDG 3 (Good Health and Well-Being), SDG 13 (Climate Action), and SDG 15 (Life on Land). By reducing soil disturbance, maintaining permanent cover, and diversifying crops, conservation agriculture builds healthy soils that are more productive and resilient to stress (Francaviglia et al., 2023). This contributes to food security and supports the sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, crucial for achieving SDG 15.

Conservation agriculture enhances soil fertility, reduces erosion, and boosts biodiversity, supporting diverse crop production and improving dietary diversity and nutritional quality (Kumawat et al., 2023). This approach aligns with SDG 2, which aims to end hunger, achieve food security, and promote sustainable agriculture. By minimizing chemical inputs, conservation agriculture improves crop quality and ecosystem services, which supports SDG 3′s focus on ensuring healthy lives and well-being. The three pillars create a sustainable agricultural system that is resilient, productive, and environmentally sound. These practices work together to nurture soil health, ensure food security, and promote human health. Embracing these principles can advance progress toward the Sustainable Development Goals, particularly those related to agriculture, health, and environmental sustainability. Conservation agriculture offers a balanced approach to meeting the needs of a growing population while protecting and restoring vital natural resources.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conclusions
ce:section.ce:para: The increased use of inorganic fertilizers in smallholder farming significantly boosts crop yields, which enhances food security and indirectly raises agricultural incomes, thus aiding in poverty alleviation. However, economic restrictions frequently limit smallholders' capacity to apply fertilizers in a manner that maximises net returns. The profitability of fertilizer use depends on the nutrient, crop and application rate. Smallholder farmers must carefully balance their limited resources to optimise fertilizer investments and increase yields. This emphasizes the critical relevance of low-cost fertilizer methods in promoting agricultural sustainability and alleviating poverty. Human-induced nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) burdens now exceed natural flows, with nitrogen loads increasing exponentially faster than P and potassium (K). Elevated NP ratios globally have a substantial influence on ecosystems and their functions, hindering healthy food production.

Using smart and eco-friendly farming techniques along with advanced biotechnology can solve the global problem of using fertilizers sustainably. By applying the 4R approach (Right Source, Right Rate, Right Time, Right Place) right away, we can manage fertilizers better, boost crop yields, and support both food security and environmental health. Poverty alleviation is critical for preventing conflict and environmental degradation, although it is not always associated with agricultural productivity or resource shortages. Understanding these intricacies is critical for long-term solutions that promote societal stability, environmental preservation and efficient resource management. Soil research is essential for understanding the relationship between soil and humans and its importance for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. Adoption of nature-based solutions like using farm manure, green manures and legume crops, promoting horticulture, practicing zero tillage and managing crop residues can help improve soil health, food and nutritional security.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Prospects
ce:section.ce:para: Farmers' reliance on NPK treatment without sufficient soil testing has resulted in nutrient imbalances, reducing the effectiveness of essential nutrients for plants. Deteriorating soil health causes significant yield gaps between prospective and actual harvests. Even bio-fortified crop varieties may produce nutrient-poor produce in the absence of adequate soil nutrients, endangering human and animal health. Urgent action is required to reverse this land degradation trend. National programs aimed at quadrupling farmers' incomes through infrastructure, technology, policy and institutional improvements provide hope for addressing these difficulties. Improving the knowledge delivery system necessitates novel ways such as para-extension workers, IT tools, and localized decision support systems, which are critical for reaching a large number of small farmers. Fig. 9 depicts the strategies for ensuring food security through balanced fertilization. The emphasis on soil research in conjunction with technology development and implementation guarantees that technology is relevant to farmers.
